'''Margie Evans''' (born July 17, 1940) is an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] singer and songwriter.<ref name="AMG"/> She recorded mainly in the 1970s and 1980s, and secured two [[hit single]]s on the [[United States|US]] ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B]] [[record chart|chart]].  She has variously worked with [[Johnny Otis]] and [[Bobby Bland]].

Her main influences were [[Bessie Smith]], [[Ma Rainey]], [[Big Maybelle]] and [[Big Mama Thornton]].<ref name="LA">{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-12-04/entertainment/ca-1497_1_margie-evans|title=Margie Evans' Wild, Wild World : Concert: The singer, who says that 'blues is so much fun for me,' travels to Europe and to Canada for the opportunity to perform|publisher=Latimes.com|date=December 4, 1992|accessdate=October 17, 2012}}</ref>

In addition to her musicianship, Evans is noted as a motivational speaker and rights activist, as well as a promoter of the legacy of blues music.<ref name="Dunbar">{{cite book
| first= Julie C.
| last= Dunbar
| year= 2011
| title= Women, Music, Culture: An Introduction
| edition= 1st
| publisher= [[Routledge]] 
| location= [[New York City|New York]], United States
| isbn= 0-203-83477-1
| page= 172}}</ref>

==Life and career==
'''Marjorie Ann Johnson''' was born in [[Shreveport, Louisiana]], [[United States]].<ref name="whitburnr&b"/> Raised as a devout church goer, Evans early exposure to music was via [[Gospel music|gospel]].<ref name="Lipsitz">{{cite book
| first= George
| last= Lipsitz
| year= 2010
| title= Midnight at the Barrelhouse: The Johnny Otis Story
| edition= 1st
| publisher= [[University of Minnesota Press]] 
| location= [[Minneapolis]], [[Minnesota]], United States
| isbn= 978-0-8166-6678-2
| pages= 142/4}}</ref> In 1958, she moved to [[Los Angeles]]. She initially sang as a [[backing vocalist]] with [[Billy Ward and His Dominoes|Billy Ward]] between 1958 and 1964, before joining the Ron Marshall Orchestra between 1964 and 1969.  She then successfully auditioned to join [[Johnny Otis]] Band.<ref name="whitburnr&b">{{cite book |title= Top R&B/Hip-Hop Singles: 1942-1995|last=Whitburn |first=Joel |authorlink=Joel Whitburn |year=1996 |publisher=Record Research |page=297}}</ref> During her four year stay there, she performed on ''The Johnny Otis Show Live at Monterey'' and ''Cuttin' Up'' [[album]]s. In addition to her recording and performing duties, Evans used her influence to help set up the Southern California Blues Society to help promote the art form through education and sponsorship.<ref name="Lipsitz"/> 

Evans commenced her solo career in 1973, and found almost immediate chart success.  Her track "Good Feeling" (United Artists 246) entered the R&B chart on June 30, 1973 for four weeks, reaching number 55. However, it was another four years before "Good Thing Queen - Part 1" (ICA 002) entered the same chart listing on July 9, 1977 for eight weeks, peaking at number 47.<ref name="whitburnr&b"/> In 1975 she supplied backing vocals on [[Donald Byrd]]'s album, ''[[Stepping into Tomorrow]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/stepping-into-tomorrow-mw0000057832/credits|title=Stepping into Tomorrow > Credits|publisher=Allmusic|accessdate=October 17, 2012}}</ref>

Also sandwiched between these hits, in November 1975, Evans appeared on German television filmed at the Berlin based Jazz Tage concert with [[Johnny "Guitar" Watson]], [[Bo Diddley]] and [[James Booker]].<ref name="Bakker">{{cite book
| first= Vincent
| last= Bakker
| year= 2009
| title= The Gangster of Love: Johnny "Guitar" Watson: Performer, Preacher, Pimp
| edition= 1st
| publisher= CreateSpace 
| location= 
| isbn= 1442141476
| page= 298}}</ref> Using Bobby Bland as her record producer and part-time song writing partner, Evans co-wrote the song "Soon As the Weather Breaks", which reached number 76 (R&B) for Bland in 1980.<ref name="whitburnr&b"/><ref name="Farley">{{cite book
| first= Charles
| last= Farley
| year= 2011
| title= Soul of the Man: Bobby "Blue" Bland
| edition= 1st
| publisher= [[University Press of Mississippi]] 
| location= [[Minneapolis]], [[Minnesota]], United States
| isbn= 978-1-60473-919-0
| page= 188}}</ref>

In 1980, Evans performed at the [[San Francisco Blues Festival]] and [[Long Beach Blues Festival]], repeating the feat at the latter a year later.  Her touring saw Evans take part in the [[American Folk Blues Festival]]s in 1981, 1982 and 1985.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wirz.de/music/afbffrm.htm|title=American Folk Blues Festival Discography|publisher=Wirz.de|accessdate=October 17, 2012}}</ref> In 1983, Evans was granted the Keepin' the Blues Alive Award by the [[Blues Foundation]].<ref name="LA"/>

Still performing into the early 1990s, Evans toured the States, Canada and Europe as well as appearing with [[Jay McShann]] at the [[Toronto Jazz Festival]].<ref name="LA"/> In the same decade, Evans continued her welfare work, by helping to organise the 5-4 Optimist Club for children from the South Central Los Angeles district.<ref name="Lipsitz"/>  Her 1996 album, ''Drowning in the Sea of Love'' is her most recent recorded output.<ref name="AMG"/>
